  <description>Characterize lines by their slope–intercept form y = m x + b or by a single parameter (e.g. angle θ). Randomly chosen points impose a distribution on these parameters, allowing you to integrate over allowed slopes or angles.</description>
  <example>For two random points in a unit square, the slope m of the line through them is a random variable. You can compute the probability that m lies in an interval [m₁, m₂] by integrating the joint density of the two points over that region.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Identify when a line intersects a specific pair of opposite edges by expressing the intersection condition in terms of the line’s parameter. Solve the resulting linear inequalities to find the range of parameters for which intersection occurs.</description>
  <example>Given a line with slope m and y-intercept b, it intersects the left vertical edge x = 0 when y = b ≥ 0 and the right edge x = 1 when y = m + b ≤ 1. Solving these gives a region in (m,b)-space where intersection happens.</example>
</note3>
<note5>
  <description>Use symmetry to reduce the number of distinct cases. In a regular polygon, opposite edges are symmetric under rotation, so you can compute the probability for one pair and multiply by the number of such pairs.</description>
  <example>In a regular hexagon, there are three pairs of opposite edges. Finding the probability that a random line intersects one pair and then multiplying by three gives the total probability for all opposite edges.</example>
</note2>

<note1>
  <description>For a regular polygon with an even number of sides, opposite edges are symmetric under the 180° rotation. A line drawn through two random interior points will intersect two opposite edges exactly when the angle between those two points lies in the range where their projection onto the polygon’s circumcircle falls between the antipodal arcs of those edges.</description>
  <example>In a regular hexagon, label its edges E₁…E₆ in order. Opposite edges are E₁–E₄, E₂–E₅, E₃–E₆. If two random points P and Q lie on the circumcircle, the chord PQ intersects E₁ and E₄ precisely when the arc from P to Q spans the 60° sector between E₁ and E₄.</example>
</note2>
  <description>The probability that a random chord intersects a given pair of opposite edges equals the ratio of the measure of the favorable arc (where the chord can lie) to the total circumference. This reduces a geometric probability to a simple angular fraction.</description>
  <example>In a circle, opposite edges correspond to a 180° arc. To find the probability that a chord intersects those edges, compute the probability that two uniformly random points on the circle lie within a 60° sector; that probability is 60°/360°.</example>
</note3>
  <description>Exploit rotational symmetry: by rotating the polygon or its circumcircle so that one opposite edge is aligned with a reference direction, the probability for that edge pair becomes the same as for any other. Thus one can compute for one pair and multiply by the number of pairs if needed.</description>
  <example>For a regular hexagon, there are 3 pairs of opposite edges. After computing the probability for a specific pair, multiply by 3 to get the total probability of intersecting any opposite-edge pair.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Use the fact that the angle between two random points on a circle is uniformly distributed over [0,π]. The likelihood that this angle falls within a particular interval (e.g. between 60° and 120°) is the length of that interval divided by π.</description>
  <example>If two random points on a circle are chosen, the angle between them is uniformly distributed from 0 to π. The probability that this angle lies between 60° and 120° is (120°–60°)/180° = 60°/180°.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Partition the event into disjoint cases based on which edges are intersected. Compute the probability for each case separately and sum them, ensuring no overlap. This approach is useful when multiple edge-pairs share the same intersection criterion.</description>
  <example>In a regular hexagon, there are three disjoint cases where the chord intersects E₁–E₄, E₂–E₅, or E₃–E₆. Compute the probability for each case (they are identical by symmetry) and sum to get the total probability.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When two points are chosen uniformly in a convex polygon, the probability that the line through them crosses a specific side pair equals the proportion of all unordered pairs of points whose connecting segment intersects that side pair.</description>
  <example>In a convex quadrilateral, to find the chance the chord crosses one pair of opposite sides, count all possible unordered point-pairs and count those whose segment meets that side pair; their ratio is the desired probability.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the fact that the set of all possible directions for a line through two random points is uniformly distributed on the circle. Thus, the probability a line meets a given side pair is the average over all directions of the probability that a random line in that direction crosses the pair.</description>
  <example>For a regular pentagon, since every direction is equally likely, compute for one direction the probability a random line in that direction crosses the designated side pair, then take that value as the overall probability.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Exploit symmetry: in a regular n-gon, opposite sides are congruent and symmetrically placed. Thus, the probability that a line crosses any one chosen side pair is the same for all such pairs, reducing the problem to computing it for one pair.</description>
  <example>In a regular hexagon, all six opposite-side pairs are equivalent by symmetry, so one computes the probability for one pair and multiplies by six if needed to cover all cases.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Parametrize the random points by two independent uniform angles (or barycentric coordinates) on the circle. Then express the condition “line crosses a side pair” as an inequality in those angles, and integrate over the unit square to find the probability.</description>
  <example>For a convex polygon, let θ₁,θ₂ be two independent uniform angles. The event “line crosses a given side pair” corresponds to |θ₁–θ₂| > θ₀ for some θ₀; one integrates 1 over the region |θ₁–θ₂| > θ₀ in the unit square.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>For two randomly chosen points in a convex region, the probability that the line through them intersects a specified pair of opposite edges equals the ratio of the area of the union of two “intersection zones” (one on each edge) to the total area. This follows because only those point pairs whose midpoint lies in the union of these zones yield a line crossing the edges.</description>
  <example>In a square, the zone on one side is the set of midpoints of segments from that side to the opposite side. The union of these two zones is a rectangle whose width equals the distance between the two parallel sides and whose height is half the side length. Thus the probability is (rectangle area)/(square area).</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Parametrize each point by its distance to a reference edge, with the midpoint’s position given by the average of these distances. Then the condition “midpoint lies in a given zone” becomes an inequality on the original distances, reducing the problem to checking a simple inequality.</description>
  <example>For a triangle, let the distances from a point to the three sides be d₁,d₂,d₃. The midpoint’s distance to the first side is (d₁+d₂)/2. If the zone on that side runs from 0 to h/2, require (d₁+d₂)/2 ≤ h/2 and similarly for the other sides.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Exploit symmetry by computing the probability for one edge and multiplying by the number of symmetric edges. Since the regions for opposite edges are congruent, the total intersection probability is k times the single-edge probability, where k is the number of such pairs.</description>
  <example>In a regular hexagon, there are three pairs of opposite edges. Compute the probability that a line crosses a single edge and multiply by 3 to get the overall probability.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the fact that the midpoint of two random points in a convex polygon is uniformly distributed over its interior. Hence the event “midpoint lies in a given region” is equivalent to “random midpoint falls in that region,” simplifying the region-of-interest to a known shape.</description>
  <example>In a regular n-gon, the midpoint of two random points is uniformly distributed inside the polygon. Thus the probability that the line through them crosses an edge equals the probability that the midpoint lies in the union of the corresponding edge-zones.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Compute the area of the union of two congruent regions by adding their areas and subtracting the area of their overlap if they intersect. This principle applies whenever you need the total area covered by two shapes.</description>
  <example>For two identical rectangles of width w and height h that overlap by a strip of width Δ, the union area is 2wh − Δh. This formula extends to any two congruent regions.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Use the expectation operator on a sum of independent indicators to compute expected counts. For each event of interest, form an indicator I that equals 1 if the event occurs and 0 otherwise; then the expected total number of events is ∑ E[I_i] = ∑ P(I_i=1).</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 10 coins and want the expected number of heads. Define I_j=1 if coin j lands heads. Then E[#heads]=∑_{j=1}^{10}E[I_j]=10·(1/2)=5.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply linearity of expectation to combine expectations of different processes or objects without requiring independence among them. This allows you to add expected values for separate events or objects even if they interact.</description>
  <example>In a random walk of 5 steps, let X=number of steps above the origin. You can write X=∑_{i=1}^5 I_i where I_i=1 if step i is +1 and previous cumulative sum was negative. Then E[X]=∑E[I_i], even though the I_i are not independent.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the law of total expectation (iterated expectation) to break a complex expectation into conditional parts. For any random times T and events A, E[T]=E[E[T|A]]+E[E[T|¬A]]. This is especially useful when the process splits into different regimes.</description>
  <example>Consider a process that continues until either event A occurs or an external event B occurs. Let T be the total time. Then E[T]=E[E[T|A]]+E[E[T|B]], where E[T|A] is the expected time given A happens first, and E[T|B] is the expected time given B happens first.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>When two merging entities combine, their expected times to absorption can be combined via the convolution of their distributions. If one entity has expected time a and the other has expected time b, the merged entity’s expected time is the convolution of their distributions, which often simplifies to (a+b)/2.</description>
  <example>Two independent processes each have expected times a and b to reach a final state. If they merge and share resources, the expected time for the merged process is often (a+b)/2, reflecting the combined effort.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Model the merging process as a discrete Markov chain by tracking the number of active groups. Compute the expected time to absorption by solving the system of first-step equations for each state.</description>
  <example>Let X_n be the number of groups at time n. Write E[T|X_n=k] = 1 + ∑_{m}P(X_{n+1}=m|X_n=k)·E[T|X_{n+1}=m]. Solve these equations to find E[T|X_0=K].</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>In a Markov chain with a finite state space, the expected time to reach an absorbing state starting from any state is given by solving the linear system E_i = 1 + Σ_{j≠absorbing} P_{i→j}·E_j for all non-absorbing states i.</description>
  <example>Consider a 4-state chain with states A, B, C, D where D is absorbing. If from A one moves to B with probability 1/2 and to C with probability 1/2, then E_A = 1 + (1/2)E_B + (1/2)E_C. Similarly, derive E_B and E_C by their outgoing probabilities, then solve the 3×3 system.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>For a process on a cycle of length N, the probability of returning to a given starting vertex after k steps is P_k = (1/N)·(1 + 2·Σ_{d|k} cos(2πd/N)). This uses the cycle’s eigenstructure.</description>
  <example>On a cycle of length 5, the probability of returning to the start after 4 steps is P_4 = (1/5)(1 + 2(cos(2π/5) + cos(4π/5))). One computes each cosine term and sums them to get the final probability.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>When two or more discrete random variables are independent, the probability that none occurs in a given trial is the product of their complementary probabilities. Summing this over trials yields the probability that at least one event occurs in at least one trial.</description>
  <example>Suppose one variable has success probability p and another has success probability q, and they are independent. The probability that neither happens in a single trial is (1–p)(1–q). If trials are repeated n times, the probability that at least one event occurs in any trial is 1 – [(1–p)(1–q)]^n.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When a system’s state changes by a fixed increment each time, the expected time to reach a threshold from an initial state k with increment d is E = (threshold – k)/d, provided each step is equally likely to increase by d.</description>
  <example>If a counter starts at 3 and increases by 2 each step with probability 1, the expected number of steps to reach 11 is (11–3)/2 = 4.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Use indicator variables to count events: for each potential collision or merge, define an indicator that is 1 if the event occurs and 0 otherwise. Then the expected total number of such events over a process equals the sum of the individual probabilities.</description>
  <example>In a sequence of n trials, let I_i be 1 if a specific event happens on trial i and 0 otherwise. Then the expected number of times the event occurs is E[I] = Σ_i P(I_i), since each I_i is 1 only if that trial triggers the event.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply linearity of expectation: regardless of dependencies between events, the expected value of the sum of random variables equals the sum of their expectations. This lets you compute complex expected counts by summing simpler probabilities.</description>
  <example>Suppose you flip a biased coin m times and want the expected number of heads. Define X_k as the indicator of heads on flip k. Then E[Σ_k X_k] = Σ_k P(heads)=m·p, even if flips are independent or not.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Model the process as a Markov chain by states defined by the number of snakes. Identify transition probabilities between states (e.g., moving from k snakes to k−1 or k+1) and use the law of total probability to find the expected time to reach a target state.</description>
  <example>Consider a process where you have k tokens and each step either removes one token with probability p or adds one with probability q. Define T_k as the expected steps to absorb to 0. Then T_k = 1 + p·T_{k−1} + q·T_{k+1}, which you solve via boundary conditions.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the general formula for the expected number of steps to absorption in a birth–death chain with two absorbing states: if at state i the process transitions to i±1 with probabilities p_i and q_i, then the expected time to absorption is T_i = 1 + p_i·T_{i−1} + q_i·T_{i+1}, with T_0=T_N=0.</description>
  <example>In a chain on states 0→1→…→N with p_i and q_i as given, solve the linear system T_0=0, T_N=0, and for i=1,…,N−1 compute T_i = 1 + p_i·T_{i−1} + q_i·T_{i+1} to find T_1, the expected absorption time from state 1.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>For large or continuous processes, approximate the expected time using differential equations or continuous-time approximations. Replace discrete steps by infinitesimal rates to derive a differential equation for the expected time as a function of the current state.</description>
  <example>In a continuous-time model where the rate of decrease of a quantity x is given by −r(x), the expected time to reach absorption at x=0 starting from x₀ satisfies dE/dx = r(x). Solve dE = (1/r(x))dx to get E(x₀) = ∫_{0}^{x₀} (1/r(u)) du.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>In a Markov chain on a circle or line with symmetric transition probabilities, the distance between two nearest merged snakes remains a valid state variable. When two snakes merge, subtract the smaller of their distances to the merged snake, preserving the invariant that the minimum distance between any two snakes never exceeds the total number of arcs.</description>
  <example>Suppose two snakes are 4 arcs apart and merge. The new distance to the nearest other snake is 4 minus the smaller of 4 and the new snake’s distance, ensuring the minimum distance stays ≤ total arcs.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When merging two snakes of lengths L₁ and L₂, the merged snake’s length is L₁+L₂ and its initial position is the midpoint (rounded) of the interval. This follows from the fact that each snake moves independently, so the merged object’s center is the average of the two centers.</description>
  <example>Two snakes of lengths 3 and 2 merge into a length-5 snake at the center of the interval between their original positions, ensuring symmetry and consistency with independent random motion.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Define the absorption time T as the number of moves until only one snake remains. Compute E[T∣state S] by averaging over all possible moves: E[T∣S] = 1 + ∑_{S′→S} P(S→S′)·E[T∣S′], where S′→S means merging two snakes that touched in one move. This yields a linear system whose solution gives E[T] in the initial state.</description>
  <example>From a state with two snakes of lengths 2 and 3, one merge takes probability 1/2, yielding a single snake of length 5 in the next state S′, while the other move leaves the same state S. Thus E[T∣S] = 1 + (1/2)·E[T∣S′] + (1/2)·E[T∣S].</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>When the state space is symmetric under relabeling of snakes (e.g., exchangeable lengths), absorption times for equivalent states coincide. Use this symmetry to reduce the size of the linear system by grouping states with the same multiset of lengths. This drastically cuts down on redundant variables.</description>
  <example>Instead of tracking each state with lengths (1,2), (2,1), and (3), note that (1,2) and (2,1) yield identical expected absorption times, so one variable suffices for both, simplifying the system.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When two triangles share a common side and both have all sides equal, they are congruent by the Side-Side-Side (SSS) criterion. Use this to assert that corresponding angles and segments are equal.</description>
  <example>Given triangles PQR and P′QR with PQ = P′Q, PR = P′R, and QR = Q′R, conclude ∠P = ∠P′ and RP = R′P.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Reflecting a point across another point (half-turn) preserves distances. For any point X and center M, XM = MX′, where X′ is the image of X under reflection across M.</description>
  <example>Reflect vertex X across point M to get X′. Then MX = MX′, and line segments through M parallel to XX′ remain parallel.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>In a regular hexagon (or any equiangular polygon), parallel lines drawn through alternate vertices are parallel. This follows from equal interior angles, ensuring corresponding lines never meet.</description>
  <example>In hexagon WXYZVU, side WX is parallel to side YZ, and side XY is parallel to side ZV, since each pair of alternate sides subtends equal angles.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>The sum of interior angles of an n-gon is (n–2)·180°. In a regular n-gon, each interior angle is (n–2)·180°/n, and each exterior angle is 360°/n.</description>
  <example>For a regular hexagon (n=6), each interior angle is (6–2)·180°/6 = 120°, and each exterior angle is 360°/6 = 60°.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle, the altitude from any vertex bisects the opposite side and is given by (side)/√3. This relation is useful for computing heights or distances in symmetric configurations.</description>
  <example>For an equilateral triangle of side length s, the altitude h satisfies h = s/√3. Thus, if s = 10, then h = 10/√3 ≈ 5.77.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Use the Law of Cosines in any triangle to relate side lengths and the cosine of the included angle: for sides a, b, c opposite angles A, B, C, c² = a² + b² − 2ab·cos C. This connects known lengths to unknown angles or vice versa.</description>
  <example>In a triangle with sides of length 5, 7, and 8, to find the angle opposite the side of length 8, compute cos C = (5² + 7² − 8²)/(2·5·7) = (25 + 49 − 64)/70 = 10/70 = 1/7, so C = arccos(1/7).</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply Stewart’s theorem for a cevian in a triangle with sides a, b, c and cevian length d splitting side a into segments m and n (m + n = a): b²·m + c²·n = a(d² + m·n). Use it to find a cevian length when the base is divided.</description>
  <example>In triangle with sides 10, 13, 15 and a cevian from the vertex opposite side 10 that divides it into segments 6 and 4, Stewart’s theorem gives 13²·6 + 15²·4 = 10(d² + 6·4). Compute 169·6 + 225·4 = 10(d² + 24) ⇒ 1014 + 900 = 10d² + 240 ⇒ 10d² = 1774 ⇒ d² = 177.4 ⇒ d = √177.4.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Exploit symmetry or rotation by 60° in equilateral triangles to create congruent triangles and equal angles. Rotating one triangle by 60° about a vertex can map points to new positions, yielding equal lengths after rotation.</description>
  <example>Given an equilateral triangle with side length s, rotate it by +60° about one vertex. A point P on one side maps to P′ so that PP′ = s and the angle at the rotated vertex is 60°. This can help relate distances from the original vertex to P and P′.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Use the Law of Sines in triangles sharing an angle or side: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C. It is especially useful when two angles and one side are known (AAS or ASA) or when two sides and a non-included angle are known (SSA).</description>
  <example>In a triangle where angles A = 50°, B = 60° and side a = 8, compute side b = a·sin B/sin A = 8·sin 60°/sin 50° ≈ 8·(0.866/0.766) ≈ 8·1.131 ≈ 9.048.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Verify constructions and computed lengths by checking geometric invariants: equilateral triangles have equal sides and 60° angles, and cyclic points satisfy equal inscribed angles subtending the same arc.</description>
  <example>After constructing an equilateral triangle, measure all three sides to confirm they are equal and all three angles to confirm they are 60°. If a point lies on a circle, check that inscribed angles subtending the same chord are equal.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When two triangles share an altitude to the same base, their areas are proportional to the lengths of the bases. Equivalently, the ratio of two triangles sharing the same height is the ratio of their bases. This holds for any segment on a common line.</description>
  <example>Triangle PQR has base QR of length b₁ and altitude h. Triangle PRS shares the same altitude h to base RS of length b₂. Then Area(PQR)/Area(PRS) = b₁/b₂.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>The area of a triangle can be expressed as ½·(base)·(height). Use this whenever you know or can determine a base and its corresponding altitude. It is fundamental for computing or comparing areas.</description>
  <example>For triangle ABC, let BC be the base of length b and the altitude from A to BC be h. Then Area(ABC) = ½·b·h. If b and h are known, compute the area directly.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle of side length s, the altitude and the median coincide and have length (s·√3)/2. This follows from dropping a perpendicular from a vertex to the opposite side, creating two 30-60-90 right triangles.</description>
  <example>Triangle XYZ is equilateral with side s. Dropping a perpendicular from X to side YZ yields a right triangle with hypotenuse s and shorter leg s/2. The altitude is √(s² – (s/2)²) = (s·√3)/2.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>When a point lies inside a triangle, the areas of the three subtriangles formed by connecting that point to the triangle’s vertices sum to the area of the whole triangle. This provides a way to relate distances from the point to the sides.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, let P be inside. Triangles PAB, PBC, and PCA have areas A₁, A₂, A₃ respectively. Then A₁ + A₂ + A₃ = Area(ABC). If A₁ and A₂ are known, A₃ = Area(ABC) – A₁ – A₂.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>To find the distance from a point inside a triangle to a side, use the area formula: if a triangle has area A and base length b, then the corresponding altitude (distance from the opposite vertex to the base) is 2A/b. This lets you compute the perpendicular distance from a point to a line.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, area A and base BC of length b. Let h be the altitude from A to BC, so h = 2A/b. If you know the area and base length, compute the altitude directly. This method generalizes to any side of the triangle.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When an equilateral triangle is constructed externally on a segment, its altitude equals (side × √3)/2, and its circumradius equals (side)/√3. This lets you locate the apex by rotating the base segment by ±60° about one endpoint by a distance equal to the side.</description>
  <example>Given a segment of length s, construct an equilateral triangle on one end by rotating the segment by 60° and scaling by s. The apex is at a distance s from the original endpoint, perpendicular to the base.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>In a triangle with two equal sides, the altitude from the apex to the base bisects the base. Thus, if you drop an altitude into an isosceles triangle, the base is split into two equal segments of length half the base.</description>
  <example>For an isosceles triangle with base length b and equal sides of length s, dropping the altitude from the apex splits the base into two segments of length b/2, and the altitude height is √(s²–(b/2)²).</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>The Law of Cosines generalizes the Pythagorean theorem: in any triangle with sides a, b, and c opposite angles A, B, C, c² = a² + b² – 2ab·cos(C). Use it to compute a side when two sides and their included angle are known, or to find an angle when all three sides are known.</description>
  <example>For a triangle with sides a=5, b=7, and included angle C=120°, the third side c satisfies c² = 5² + 7² – 2·5·7·cos(120°) = 25 + 49 + 35 = 109, so c = √109.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>When multiple triangles share a common vertex or side, summing their areas yields the total area. Alternatively, subtracting the areas of known triangles from a larger figure can isolate the area of the unknown one.</description>
  <example>Suppose a large triangle has area T, and two subtriangles inside it have areas A₁ and A₂. The remaining triangle’s area is T – A₁ – A₂, which can help find unknown side lengths via area formulas.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Coordinate geometry transforms geometric constructions into algebraic calculations. Place key points at convenient coordinates, compute side lengths using the distance formula, and solve for unknown coordinates or lengths using algebraic equations.</description>
  <example>Place one endpoint of a segment at (0,0) and the other at (d,0). If an equilateral triangle is constructed on this segment, its apex has coordinates ((d)/2, (d·√3)/2). Use these to compute distances to other points.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When four points form a square, the squared distance between any two adjacent vertices equals the side squared, and the squared distance between two opposite vertices equals twice the side squared. This follows from the Pythagorean theorem applied to the side and diagonal.</description>
  <example>Given four points A, B, C, D in order, compute AB² and AC². If AB² = s² and AC² = 2s², then A, B, C, D form a square of side s.</example>
</note2>
  <description>Translate each point into a vector from a common origin or coordinate system, then form dot products and magnitudes. The condition for square adjacency is that the dot product of adjacent vectors equals zero (orthogonality) and their magnitudes are equal.</description>
  <example>Let P₁ = (x₁,y₁), P₂ = (x₂,y₂). Then vectors v = P₂–P₁ and w = P₃–P₂ satisfy v·w = 0 and |v| = |w| if P₁, P₂, P₃ form a right angle with equal legs.</example>
</note3>
  <description>Match the squared distances between points from different sets by equating expressions. For example, if one point set has squared lengths L₁² and L₂², and another has squared heights H₁² and H₂², set (L₁² + H₁²) = (L₂² + H₂²) to enforce equal distances under different orientations.</description>
  <example>Suppose two stalactites of lengths L₁, L₂ and two stalagmites of heights H₁, H₂ form a square. Then (L₁² + H₁²) = (L₂² + H₂²) must hold, yielding an equation relating H₁ and H₂.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Use symmetry: in a square, opposite pairs of points are mirror images across the center. Thus, if one point’s height is h, the opposite point’s height is 2H–h, where H is the total height of the structure.</description>
  <example>If the ceiling is at height H and a stalactite’s tip is at height H–L₁, its opposite stalagmite’s tip must be at height H–(2H–(H–L₁)) = H–L₁, enforcing consistency with symmetry.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Check for degenerate or invalid configurations by verifying that computed distances are positive and that no point lies inside the square’s boundary. Also ensure that the square’s side length is positive and finite.</description>
  <example>A computed side length s = 0 would indicate collinear points, while negative s indicates an impossible arrangement. Discard any configuration that fails these checks.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When four points form a square in the plane, the sum of the squares of two opposite edge-lengths equals twice the square of the diagonal. Formally, if two opposite sides have lengths a and b, then a² + b² = d², where d is the diagonal.</description>
  <example>Suppose two opposite edges of a quadrilateral have lengths 3 and 4. Then the diagonal connecting their opposite vertices must satisfy 3² + 4² = d², so d = 5.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>In a square, each side is perpendicular to its adjacent sides, and the distance between two parallel sides equals the side length. This ensures that all four angles are right angles and all sides are equal.</description>
  <example>If you have a quadrilateral with four right angles and four equal lengths of 6, then it must be a square, and the distance between any two parallel sides is 6.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When projecting perpendicular lengths onto a horizontal or vertical line, the squared difference of their endpoints equals the square of the vertical or horizontal separation. That is, if two vertical segments of heights h₁ and h₂ project to the same horizontal line, then (h₁ – h₂)² is the horizontal distance squared.</description>
  <example>Two vertical posts of heights 10 and 4 lie in the plane. The horizontal distance between their bases satisfies (10 – 4)² = 36, so the distance is 6.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>For two perpendicular segments of lengths a and b, the distance between their endpoints is √(a² + b²). This follows from the Pythagorean theorem in the plane.</description>
  <example>A rope of length 5 is tied horizontally, and a vertical pole of length 12 is erected perpendicular to the rope at one end. The distance from the other end of the rope to the top of the pole is √(5² + 12²) = 13.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When the sum of two perpendicular lengths equals a given total, each length can be found by solving the system a + b = S and a² + b² = D². Substituting b = S – a into a² + b² = D² yields a quadratic in a.</description>
  <example>Given a + b = 10 and a² + b² = 58, substitute b = 10 – a to get a² + (10 – a)² = 58, which simplifies to 2a² – 20a + 58 = 0. Solving this quadratic gives the two possible values for a.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When two segments of lengths a and b are endpoints of a square’s diagonal, the side length s satisfies s² = (a² + b²)/2 via the Pythagorean relation for the diagonal.</description>
  <example>For diagonal lengths 1 and 2, compute s = √((1² + 2²)/2) = √(1 + 4)/2 = √(5/2).</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>A square’s area A can be expressed in two ways: A = side² and A = diagonal²/2. Equating these gives side² = diagonal²/2, useful when the diagonal is known.</description>
  <example>If a square’s diagonal measures d, then its side is s = d/√2, and its area is A = (d/√2)² = d²/2.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>When four lengths are arranged around a square, opposite pairs must satisfy the relation a² + c² = b² + d² so that the total area from each pair equals. This ensures the four segments can form a square.</description>
  <example>Given segments of lengths 3, 4, 5, and 6, check 3² + 5² = 4² + 6² → 9 + 25 = 16 + 36 → 34 = 52 (not equal). Thus they cannot form a square.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>For a square inscribed by perpendicular segments from two parallel planes, the total height H is the vertical separation between planes plus the vertical projection of the square’s diagonal. Use H = H₀ + s√2 to find H₀ when H and s are known.</description>
  <example>If the square’s side is s = 5 and the total height H is 10, then the plane separation is H₀ = H – s√2 = 10 – 5√2.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Any square’s diagonal relates to its side s by d = s·√2, so if four points form a square, the distances between opposite pairs must both equal d = s·√2. This lets you set up equations linking side lengths and diagonals.</description>
  <example>Suppose four points P, Q, R, S form a square. Then PQ = QR = RS = SP = s and PR = QS = s·√2. If PR = 10, then s = 10/√2 = 5√2.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>In a right triangle, the Pythagorean theorem a² + b² = c² applies to any perpendicular segments. Use it to compute unknown heights or horizontal offsets when two perpendicular lengths meet at a right angle.</description>
  <example>Given a vertical height h and horizontal offset d, the slanted distance L satisfies L² = h² + d². For instance, if h = 3 and d = 4, then L = 5.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When two segments of lengths a and b form a right angle, the distance between their endpoints is √(a² + b²). This is key for computing the distance between any two perpendicular structures.</description>
  <example>A vertical stalactite of length a = 5 and a horizontal stalagmite of length b = 12 meet at right angles. The distance between their tips is √(5² + 12²) = 13.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>To place a square in a plane, choose one side along a known direction and rotate it by 45° to align diagonals with the other direction. The side’s length is then the diagonal length divided by √2.</description>
  <example>Given a diagonal of length D, the side of the square is s = D/√2. If D = 14, then s = 14/√2 = 7√2.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>After constructing a square’s vertices, compute its height by finding the maximum y-coordinate of the vertices minus the minimum y-coordinate. This gives the vertical span of the square.</description>
  <example>If the vertices have y-coordinates y₁ = 2, y₂ = 2, y₃ = 6, y₄ = 6, then the square’s height is 6 − 2 = 4.</example>

<note1>
  <description>
Decompose the square into four triangles sharing vertex P and use the fact that each triangle’s area is half its base times its height. Summing these areas yields a relation between the distances from P to the sides and the side length of the square.
</description>
  <example>
In a unit square, if the areas of triangles at P to three sides are a, b, and c, then the fourth must be 1–a–b–c. Summing gives the sum of distances to the four sides, which equals 2.
</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>
Assign coordinates to the square (e.g. (0,0) to (s,s)) and let P=(x,y). Write each triangle area in terms of x and y and set them equal to the given values. This yields four linear equations in x and y.
</description>
  <example>
For a unit square, triangles at P=(x,y) to sides x=0, y=0, x=s, y=s have areas xy, y(1–x), x(1–y), and (1–x)(1–y). Setting these equal to four given values gives four equations in x and y.
</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>
Use area ratios and similar triangles to relate the distances from P to opposite sides. In a square, triangles sharing an opposite side are similar, so their areas scale as the squares of their heights.
</description>
  <example>
If the area of triangle P to side AB is A₁ and to side CD is A₂, then the heights from P to AB and CD satisfy (height to AB)/(height to CD)=√(A₁/A₂), giving a direct relation between those distances.
</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>
Compute the product of distances PA·PB·PC·PD by expressing each distance as √[2·area of triangle with that base]. Multiply these square roots or use symmetry to simplify to a single radical.
</description>
  <example>
If triangle areas are A₁, A₂, A₃, A₄, then PA·PB·PC·PD = √[2A₁]·√[2A₂]·√[2A₃]·√[2A₄] = 2·√(A₁·A₂·A₃·A₄).
</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>
Apply the British Flag Theorem: for any point inside a rectangle, the sum of the squares of distances to two opposite corners equals the sum for the other pair. This relates PA²+PC² and PB²+PD² without computing x,y.
</description>
  <example>
In a rectangle with side lengths a and b, if PA²+PC² = S, then PB²+PD² = S also. Combined with area-based sums of distances, one can compute S and hence distances PA, PB, PC, PD.
</example>

<note1>
  <description>Compute the total area by summing the areas of the four triangles. In any convex quadrilateral partitioned by a point into four triangles, the sum of those triangle areas equals the area of the quadrilateral.</description>
  <example>In a square of side length s, if the point P divides it into triangles of areas 1, 2, 3, and 4, then the square’s area is 1+2+3+4=10. If you know the side length is s, you can set s²=10.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the area formula for a triangle: area = ½·(side)·(distance to opposite side)·sin(θ). For a square of side s, each triangle area A gives a product relation dᵢ·s·sin(θᵢ)=2A, where dᵢ is the perpendicular distance from P to that side.</description>
  <example>For a triangle with area A=1 and side s, the distance to that side satisfies d·s·sin(θ)=2, so if θ=90° then d=2/s. Summing similar relations for all four sides yields equations linking distances and side length.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Apply the Law of Cosines in each triangle to relate distances: for triangle with sides d₁, d₂ and included angle θ, d₁² + d₂² – 2d₁d₂ cos θ = (known side)². This yields equations among dᵢ and cos θᵢ.</description>
  <example>In triangle PAB with P–A=d₁, P–B=d₂, and known AB=s, write d₁² + d₂² – 2d₁d₂ cos θ = s². Repeat for the other three triangles to get a system in dᵢ and cos θᵢ.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Exploit the fact that in a square, opposite sides are parallel and adjacent sides meet at right angles. This forces certain angles and distance relations, simplifying the system.</description>
  <example>Since AB ∥ CD, the angle between AP and BP equals the angle between CP and DP. Thus cos θ₁ = cos θ₃ and sin θ₁ = sin θ₃, reducing the number of distinct variables in the system.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Use symmetry or angle-sum identities to eliminate variables. For example, if θ₁+θ₂=90°, then cos θ₁ = sin θ₂, allowing substitution of one trigonometric function for another.</description>
  <example>When θ₁+θ₂=90°, replace cos θ₁ with sin θ₂ in the Law of Cosines equations. This reduces the problem to solving for d₁, d₂, d₃, d₄ in terms of s and known areas.</example>
</note6>
<note6>
  <description>After reducing the system, solve for side length s in terms of known triangle areas. Then compute the product of all relevant distances via algebraic manipulation, often yielding s to a power or a constant multiple.</description>
  <example>From the equations dᵢ·s = 2Aᵢ, express each dᵢ in terms of s. Multiply all dᵢ together to get (2A₁)(2A₂)(2A₃)(2A₄)/s², and substitute s²=total area to obtain the desired product as a constant like 4!.</example>

<note1>
  <description>For a point inside a convex quadrilateral, the sum of the areas of the four triangles formed by connecting that point to the vertices equals the quadrilateral’s total area. This lets you relate unknown distances to known area sums.</description>
  <example>In a square of side length s, if a point P creates triangles with areas a, b, c, d, then s² = a + b + c + d. Thus if a, b, c, d are given, you can recover s without computing P’s coordinates.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When the areas of triangles sharing a common side are known, use area = ½·base·height to express heights in terms of the unknown distances. This converts area data into linear relations involving those distances.</description>
  <example>Suppose triangle PAB has area A and AB = s. Then height from P to AB is h₁ = 2A/s. If another triangle PBC has area B and BC = s, its height h₂ = 2B/s. These h₁ and h₂ relate to P’s perpendicular distances to AB and BC.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Exploit symmetry or cyclic arrangements to minimize variables. In a regular polygon, rotating the configuration often produces equal-area or equal-distance relationships, reducing the number of independent unknowns.</description>
  <example>In a square, rotating the figure by 90° maps one triangle to another. If triangles created by P to adjacent sides have areas in a certain order, symmetry implies that distances to those sides can be paired, halving the unknowns.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Use the law of cosines in each triangle to express the square of each side in terms of the known distances and the angle between them. This yields equations that can be combined for a product of distances.</description>
  <example>In triangle PAB, PA² + PB² – 2·PA·PB·cos(∠APB) = AB². If AB is known and the sum of the remaining angles around P is fixed, you can form equations for PA·PB, PB·PC, etc., and multiply them to get PA·PB·PC·PD.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>After setting up the equations, look for symmetry or cancellation when multiplying all distance expressions. Often factors such as s² or cos-term products simplify dramatically, leading to a clean final expression.</description>
  <example>Multiplying PA·PB·PC·PD from each triangle yields a product of terms like (s² – h₁²)(s² – h₂²)… which simplifies to a constant multiple of s⁴, independent of P’s actual position.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Any point inside a convex quadrilateral can be split into four triangles by drawing segments to the vertices. The sum of their areas equals the total area of the quadrilateral.</description>
  <example>For Quadrilateral WXYZ and interior point Q, draw QW, QX, QY, QZ to form triangles QWX, QXY, QYZ, QZW. Then area(QWX)+area(QXY)+area(QYZ)+area(QZW)=area(WXYZ).</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>When a point is inside a square, its distances to two adjacent vertices along the sides satisfy the relation d₁·d₂ = side² for those two distances. This follows from the fact that the square’s side length is the same in both directions.</description>
  <example>In square UVWX with side length s, for any interior point R, if the distance from R to U is d₁ and to V is d₂, then d₁·d₂ = s².</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Four triangles sharing the same vertex have areas proportional to the products of the two adjacent side lengths. If the included angle is right (as in a square), each area equals ½·side₁·side₂, so side₁·side₂ = 2·area.</description>
  <example>In right triangle ABC at A, with sides AB = a and AC = b, area = ½·a·b. Hence a·b = 2·area.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>In a square, the product of distances from any interior point to two opposite vertices equals the product of the distances to the other two opposite vertices: d₁·d₃ = d₂·d₄. This follows from symmetry and the fact that each pair of opposite sides is equal.</description>
  <example>For square MNOP and interior point R, let RM·RN = d₁·d₂ and RP·RQ = d₃·d₄. Then d₁·d₃ = d₂·d₄.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Combine the relationships from notes 2, 3, and 4 to express the product of all four distances in terms of the given triangle areas. Summing the area-proportion equations and using the opposite-vertex product yields a direct formula for the total product.</description>
  <example>Given areas of four triangles around a square are a, b, c, d, and knowing a·b = 2·A, b·c = 2·B, c·d = 2·C, d·a = 2·D, along with a·c = b·d, one finds (d₁·d₂·d₃·d₄)² = (2A·2B·2C·2D).</example>

<note1>
  <description>For two circles of radii R and r with centers at distance d, the length of the common external tangent segment is √(d² – (R – r)²). This follows from dropping a perpendicular from the larger center to the tangent line, forming a right triangle.
  </description>
  <example>Two circles have radii 5 and 2 and their centers are 7 apart. The external tangent length √(7² – (5 – 2)²) = √(49 – 9) = √40 ≈ 6.32.
  </example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a smaller circle is inscribed in a larger semicircle (or circle) so that its diameter lies along the larger’s diameter and is tangent to the larger’s arc, the distance from the smaller’s center to the larger’s center equals R – r, where R is the larger radius and r the smaller. This is a special case of the tangent–radius right triangle.
  </description>
  <example>For a semicircle of radius 8 and an inscribed semicircle of radius 2, the centers are 6 apart (8 – 2), ensuring the smaller’s diameter sits on the larger’s diameter and its arc is tangent to the larger.
  </example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>In similar triangles formed by radii and tangents, corresponding sides are proportional. If two triangles share an angle and have sides parallel, then the ratio of any pair of sides equals the ratio of corresponding radii (or distances).
  </description>
  <example>In a figure with two similar right triangles, one has legs 3 and 4, the other 6 and 8. The ratio of corresponding legs 3:6 = 4:8 = 1:2, matching the ratio of their hypotenuses (5:10) and other sides.
  </example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>The Pythagorean theorem relates the legs and hypotenuse of a right triangle via a² + b² = c². In circle–tangent problems, dropping perpendiculars often creates right triangles whose side lengths can be found by this formula.
  </description>
  <example>A right triangle has one leg of length 7 and hypotenuse 25. The other leg is √(25² – 7²) = √(625 – 49) = √576 = 24.
  </example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When a line segment is divided by a point into two parts, the product of the part lengths equals the product of the external segments if the point lies on a tangent or secant from an external point. This is a special case of power of a point.
  </description>
  <example>A tangent from point P touches a circle at T, and a secant from P meets the circle at A and B. If PA = 3 and PB = 5, then PT² = PA·PB = 15, so PT = √15.
  </example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>For a chord of a circle, the perpendicular from the center to the chord bisects it. If the chord length is L and the distance from center to chord is d, then the radius R satisfies R² = d² + (L/2)². This lets you relate distances without computing angles.</description>
  <example>In a circle of radius R, a chord of length L is drawn. Drop a perpendicular from the center to meet the chord at M. Then OM = d and AM = BM = L/2. Applying the Pythagorean theorem gives R² = d² + (L/2)².</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When two circles are tangent internally, the distance between their centers equals the difference of their radii. If the larger circle has radius R and the smaller has radius r, then the centers are separated by |R–r|. This is key for locating tangency points along a line.</description>
  <example>Circle C₁ has radius R and circle C₂ has radius r, with C₂ inside C₁ and tangent at one point. The line through their centers has length |R–r|. The point of tangency lies on this line at distance R–r from the center of C₁.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>In a semicircle, a line from the center perpendicular to a chord meets the chord at its midpoint. Combined with the right-triangle relation from Note 1, this yields a simple formula for the chord length: L = 2·√(R² – d²), where d is the distance from center to chord.</description>
  <example>Consider a semicircle of radius R and a chord at distance d from the center. Draw the perpendicular from the center to the chord, meeting it at M. Then AM = BM = √(R² – d²), so the full chord length is L = 2·√(R² – d²).</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>For three semicircles in nested tangency, the distances between their centers and the chord serve as a chain of relations. One can set up ratios or differences of radii along the diameter to solve for an unknown length without solving for each center position.</description>
  <example>Let R₃, R₂, R₁ be the radii of the three semicircles in descending order, and let d₃₂, d₂₁ be the distances from the center of each to the chord. Then R₃ – R₂ = d₃₂ and R₂ – R₁ = d₂₁. Solving these gives R₂ = (R₃ + R₁)/2 and d₂₁ in terms of R₁ and R₃.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Mass point geometry can handle nested tangency problems by assigning “masses” to each circle’s center proportional to its radius. The balance condition at the chord gives the unknown segment lengths directly via mass ratios.</description>
  <example>Assign masses m₁ and m₃ to the centers of the inner and outer semicircles, proportional to R₁ and R₃. The tangency point on the chord is then the weighted average of the centers, and the distances AC and CB follow from the mass ratios m₁:m₃.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When two circles are tangent internally, the distance between their centers equals the difference of their radii. This allows one to relate the center coordinates or distances to known radii.</description>
  <example>Circle C₁ of radius r₁ is inscribed inside circle C₂ of radius r₂. If the centers are O₁ and O₂, then O₂O₁ = |r₂ − r₁|. For instance, if r₁=3 and r₂=7, then O₂O₁=4.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>For a circle inscribed in a semicircle with its diameter as a chord, the midpoint of that diameter lies on the center of the inscribed circle. This follows from the circle’s symmetry about its diameter.</description>
  <example>Suppose a circle of radius r is inscribed in a semicircle of radius R, and its diameter endpoints are D₁ and D₂. The center of the inscribed circle lies at the midpoint of D₁D₂. If D₁D₂ spans from x=0 to x=2r, then the center is at x=r.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Two diameters of nested semicircles are parallel if and only if the centers of the corresponding circles lie on a horizontal line. This alignment simplifies coordinate placement and distance calculations.</description>
  <example>Let semicircles of radii r and R have diameters parallel. Place the larger’s center at (0,0) and the smaller’s at (h,0). Then their diameters lie on the same horizontal axis, making it easy to compute h in terms of r and R.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>To find the point of tangency between a circle and a line, set the distance from the circle’s center to the line equal to the circle’s radius. Use the formula |Ax₀ + By₀ + C|/√(A²+B²) = r for line Ax+By+C=0 and center (x₀,y₀).</description>
  <example>A circle centered at (d,0) with radius r is tangent to the x-axis (line y=0). The distance from (d,0) to y=0 is |0·d + 1·0 + 0|/√1 = 0, so the tangency point is (d,0) itself. For a slope m, the condition is |m·d + 0|/√(1+m²) = r.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>The power of a point theorem states that for any point P and a circle, the product of the distances along any secant through P to the circle equals a constant (the power of P). In particular, if a secant meets the circle at points X and Y, then PX·PY is constant for all secants through P.</description>
  <example>Let P be a point on the x-axis at distance d from the y-axis. A secant through P meets a circle centered at the origin with radius r at points A and B. Then PA·PB = d² − r² for all such secants.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When a smaller semicircle is inscribed in a larger semicircle with its diameter as a chord, the center of the smaller semicircle lies at the perpendicular bisector of that chord. This follows from the fact that the center of any circle lies on the perpendicular bisector of any chord.</description>
  <example>Consider a large semicircle of radius R with diameter endpoints P and Q. A smaller semicircle is inscribed so that its diameter lies on PQ. The center of the small semicircle must lie on the line perpendicular to PQ at its midpoint M. Thus the small semicircle is centered at some point on that perpendicular bisector.</example>
</note2>
  <description>Using the Pythagorean theorem in the right triangle formed by the centers of the two semicircles and one endpoint of the chord yields a relation between their radii. Specifically, if O₁ and O₂ are the centers and r₁, r₂ are the radii, then (O₁O₂)² = (distance along the diameter)² + (r₁ + r₂)².</description>
  <example>Let O₁ be the center of the small semicircle of radius r₁, and O₂ the center of the large of radius R. If the small diameter lies on the large diameter, then O₁O₂² = (distance from O₂ to the chord)² + (r₁ + r₂)². By plugging in the known distances, one can solve for r₂ in terms of r₁ and known chord length.</example>
</note3>
  <description>For a semicircle inscribed in another, the tangency point on the chord satisfies the condition that the distance from the chord to the center of the inscribed semicircle equals its radius. This ensures the arc of the smaller semicircle just touches the chord.</description>
  <example>Given a large semicircle with diameter AB and a smaller semicircle of radius r₁ inscribed so that its diameter lies on AB, let the tangency point be C. Then the perpendicular distance from C to the center O₁ of the small semicircle is exactly r₁. This gives a linear equation involving the unknown coordinates of C.</example>
</note4>
  <description>The power of a point (PtoA) theorem states that for any point X on a line through the center of a circle, the product of the distances from X to the two intersection points with the circle is constant. In inscribed semicircles, this can relate the segments created by a chord or diameter.</description>
  <example>For a chord AB of a circle and a point C on AB, if a line through C meets the circle again at D and E, then CA·CB = CD·CE. This can be used to relate the distances AC and CB when combined with the known radius and center positions.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Homothety (scaling) between two similar semicircles can be used to relate their radii and positions. The center of homothety lies on the line joining the centers of the two semicircles, and the ratio of distances from that center to each semicircle's center equals the ratio of their radii.</description>
  <example>Let O₁ and O₂ be the centers of two semicircles with radii r₁ and r₂. A homothety centered at H with ratio r₂/r₁ maps O₁ to O₂. If the large semicircle is twice the radius of the small, then H divides O₁O₂ in the ratio 2:1. This helps locate the tangency point or relate segment lengths on the diameter.</example>

<note1>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle, the circumradius R equals side length s divided by √3, and the distance from any vertex to the centroid is 2/3 of the altitude. Use these to relate side lengths to distances to key points.</description>
  <example>In a triangle with side length s, the altitude is (√3/2)s, so the centroid-to-vertex distance is (2/3)(√3/2)s = s/√3, and the circumradius is s/√3.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>For any triangle, the Law of Cosines states that for sides a, b, c and included angle γ opposite side c, c² = a² + b² − 2ab·cos γ. Use this to compute a side or angle when two sides and the included angle (or three sides) are known.</description>
  <example>In triangle XYZ with sides XY = 4, XZ = 5, and ∠Y XZ = 60°, the opposite side YZ is √(4² + 5² − 2·4·5·cos 60°) = √(16 + 25 − 20) = √21.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>The Power of a Point theorem with respect to a circle: for a point P and a secant through P meeting the circle at X and Y, PX·PY equals the power of P. Use this to relate segment products when a point lies outside or inside a circle.</description>
  <example>Let P be outside a circle, and a line through P meets the circle at X and Y. If PX = 2 and PY = 7, then PX·PY = 14 is the power of P, which also equals the square of the tangent from P minus the square of the external segment.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Thales’ theorem: any angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle. If a triangle has one side as diameter of its circumcircle, then the angle opposite that diameter is 90°.</description>
  <example>In a circle with diameter AB, any point C on the circle satisfies ∠ACB = 90°. Thus, if AC = 3 and BC = 4, then AB = 5 by the Pythagorean theorem.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Angle chasing in cyclic quadrilaterals: opposite angles sum to 180°, and equal inscribed angles subtend equal arcs. Use these to relate unknown angles in configurations involving circles.</description>
  <example>In cyclic quadrilateral WXYZ, if ∠WXY = 70°, then ∠WZY = 110° (supplementary). If two inscribed angles at X and Y both subtend arc WZ, they are equal.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Thales’ theorem: In any circle, an angle subtended by a diameter is a right angle. Its converse states that if an angle in a triangle is 90°, the segment opposite that angle is a diameter of the circumscribed circle.</description>
  <example>Given a circle with diameter AB, any point C on the circle satisfies ∠ACB=90°. Conversely, if in triangle DEF ∠DEF=90°, then EF is the diameter of the circle passing through D, E, F.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle, the distance from any vertex to the circumcenter is equal to the side length divided by √3, and the circumradius equals 2/3 of the altitude. Use these to relate side length to distances from the center.</description>
  <example>In an equilateral triangle with side length s, the altitude is (s√3)/2, so the circumradius R = (s√3)/3. Thus, if s=10, then R=10√3/3.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Reflecting a point across the circumcenter of an equilateral triangle maps it to a point on the same circumcircle, preserving distances to the center. This can convert distance relations into known diameters or radii.</description>
  <example>Let O be the circumcenter of an equilateral triangle and P any point. Reflect P across O to P′. Then OP′=OP and both P and P′ lie on the circumcircle, so ∠P′OP is a diameter angle.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>When two circles intersect, the power of a point theorem relates the products of the lengths of the segments along each circle through that point. For two intersecting circles at X and Y, for any point P, PX·PY (for one circle) equals PX·PY (for the other).</description>
  <example>Circle1 and Circle2 meet at X and Y. If P lies on Circle1 and PX·PY=12, then for any other point Q on Circle2, QX·QY also equals 12, enabling computation of unknown segments.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>In any triangle, the Law of Cosines relates the lengths of the sides to the cosine of one angle: for sides a, b with included angle γ, the opposite side c satisfies c² = a² + b² – 2ab·cos γ. Use this to find unknown side lengths from known angles.</description>
  <example>In ΔABC, if BC=7, CA=8, and ∠C=60°, then AB² = 7² + 8² – 2·7·8·cos 60° = 49 + 64 – 112·½ = 113, so AB = √113.</example>

<note1>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle, the circumcenter, centroid, and orthocenter coincide, and the circumradius R satisfies R = side / √3. This lets you switch between side lengths and distances to vertices without extra steps.</description>
  <example>For an equilateral triangle with side length s, the distance from the center to any vertex is R = s/√3. Thus if s = 10, R = 10/√3.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>The Inscribed Angle Theorem: An angle formed by two chords in a circle is half the measure of its intercepted arc. Use this to relate angles at the circumference to arc measures.</description>
  <example>In a circle, if an inscribed angle intercepts an arc of 100°, then the angle at the circumference is 50°. Conversely, if an angle is 40°, its intercepted arc is 80°.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Power of a Point: For a point P inside a circle, if two chords through P meet the circle at U and V, and W and X, then PU·PV = PW·PX. This is useful to relate segment lengths when chords intersect inside the circle.</description>
  <example>If chords through P meet the circle at U,V and W,X, and PU = 3, PV = 5, then PW·PX = 15. If PW = 2, then PX = 7.5.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Thales’ Theorem: A triangle inscribed in a circle with its hypotenuse as a diameter is a right triangle. This identifies right angles when a diameter is used as one side.</description>
  <example>Given a circle with diameter AB, any point C on the circle forms the right triangle ABC with the right angle at C.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Reflection across a diameter: Reflecting a point across the diameter of a circle maps it to another point on the circle. This can simplify angle chasing or show congruent segments.</description>
  <example>Reflect point P across the diameter AB of a circle to get P'. Then P' lies on the circle, and for any chord through P, the reflected chord through P' is symmetric, aiding in angle or length comparisons.</example>

<note1>
  <description>In an equilateral triangle, the circumcenter, centroid, and orthocenter coincide at the same point, and the distance from any vertex to that point is two-thirds of the altitude. This lets you locate the circumcenter by dropping the altitude and measuring two-thirds of its length to the base.</description>
  <example>For an equilateral triangle of side length s, the altitude is (s·√3)/2, so the distance from a vertex to the circumcenter is (2/3)·(s·√3)/2 = (s·√3)/3.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a point P satisfies ∠BPC=120° inside triangle ABC, reflect P across BC to P′. Then ∠BPC=120° implies BP′C=60°, so BP′C is equilateral. This construction turns an angle condition into an equilateral triangle, which often yields equal side lengths.</description>
  <example>Given ∠BPC=120°, reflect P over BC to P′. In triangle BP′C, BP′=CP′=BC, and ∠BP′C=60°, so BP′C is equilateral.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>The Power of a Point theorem states that for any point P inside a circle, if a line through P meets the circle at X and Y, then PX·PY equals the power of P. In particular, for a circle with diameter AB, the power of P is PA·PB. This relation lets you relate segments when a circle is defined by a diameter.</description>
  <example>Let AB be a diameter of a circle and P any interior point. If a line through P meets the circle again at X, then PX·PY = PA·PB, where Y is the second intersection with the circle through P.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>The circumcircle of an equilateral triangle has radius R = s/√3, where s is the side length. Any point on this circumcircle satisfies the chord-length formula: for two points U and V on the circle, UV = 2R·sin(∠UOV/2), where O is the center.</description>
  <example>In an equilateral triangle of side s, the circumradius is R = s/√3. If U and V lie on the circumcircle and subtend a central angle of θ at O, then UV = 2·(s/√3)·sin(θ/2).</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When two circles intersect, the radical axis (the line of points with equal power to both circles) is perpendicular to the line joining their centers. If the radical axis also passes through a known point, it can be used to locate intersection points by dropping perpendiculars from centers to that axis.</description>
  <example>Circles centered at O₁ and O₂ intersect. Their radical axis is ℓ. If a known point P lies on ℓ, then the line through P perpendicular to O₁O₂ meets the circles at the intersection points X and Y.</example>

<note1>
  <description>The circumcenter of a triangle is the intersection of its perpendicular bisectors, and it is equidistant from all three vertices. For any triangle with side lengths a, b, c opposite vertices A, B, C, the circumcenter’s position can be found by solving the bisector equations or by using coordinates for convenient computation.</description>
  <example>Given triangle with vertices at (0,0), (a,0), and (0,b), its perpendicular bisectors of the sides between (0,0)-(a,0) and (0,0)-(0,b) intersect at the circumcenter, which lies at (a/2, b/2). This point is equidistant from all three vertices.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>For a triangle with side lengths a, b, c, the circumradius R satisfies R = (a b c)/(4K), where K is the triangle’s area. This comes from the extended law of sines: c/sin(C)=2R, and K = ½ab sin(C). It’s useful for finding distances from the circumcenter to vertices without computing all bisectors.</description>
  <example>In a triangle with sides 5, 6, 7, the area is √[s(s−5)(s−6)(s−7)] with s=9, giving K=10. Then R = (5·6·7)/(4·10) = 210/40 = 5.25, so the circumcenter is 5.25 units from each vertex.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>The area of a convex quadrilateral with vertex coordinates (x₁,y₁), (x₂,y₂), (x₃,y₃), (x₄,y₄) can be computed by dividing it into two triangles (e.g. (1–2–3) and (1–3–4)) and summing their areas: ½|x₁y₂−x₂y₁ + x₂y₃−x₃y₂ + x₃y₄−x₄y₃ + x₄y₁−x₁y₄|. This avoids special formulas for cyclic or trapezoidal cases.</description>
  <example>For quadrilateral with vertices (0,0),(2,0),(3,1),(1,2), compute two triangle areas: ½|0·0−2·0 + 2·1−3·0 + 3·2−1·1 + 1·0−0·2| = ½|0+2+6−1+0| = 7/2. The total is 7/2.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>In a trapezoid with parallel sides of lengths L₁ and L₂ and height h, the midpoints of the non-parallel sides form a segment of length (L₁+L₂)/2, which is the average of the bases. This mid-segment is parallel to the bases and has length equal to the average of the lengths of the two bases.</description>
  <example>For a trapezoid with top base 6 and bottom base 10 and height 4, the mid-segment between the midpoints of the legs is (6+10)/2 = 8, parallel to the bases, and its distance from each base is half the height, i.e. 2.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When two points are equidistant from the endpoints of a segment, they lie on the perpendicular bisector of that segment. If three such points each lie on a distinct perpendicular bisector of two sides of a triangle, their intersection is the circumcenter. This criterion helps locate the circumcenter via bisector intersections.</description>
  <example>In triangle with vertices A, B, C, let P be equidistant from A and B, and Q equidistant from B and C. Then P and Q lie on the perpendicular bisectors of AB and BC, respectively. Their intersection O is the circumcenter of triangle ABC.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Four points lie on a common circle if and only if the perpendicular bisectors of any two connecting segments intersect at a single point. This “perpendicular bisector intersection” test is used to identify cyclic quadrilaterals and to locate their circumcenter.</description>
  <example>Given points P, Q, R, and S, draw the perpendicular bisectors of PQ and QR. If they meet at O, then O is the circumcenter of ΔPQR. To confirm all four points lie on a circle, check the bisector of RS also passes through O.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>The circumcenter of any triangle is equidistant from its three vertices, so the distance from the circumcenter to each vertex is the triangle’s circumradius. This radius can be computed via R = (abc)/(4Δ), where a, b, c are side lengths and Δ is the triangle’s area.</description>
  <example>In ΔXYZ with sides x, y, z and area Δ, compute R = (x·y·z)/(4Δ). Then the circumcenter O satisfies OX = OY = OZ = R, ensuring O is equidistant from all three vertices.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>A polygon formed by connecting the circumcenters of adjacent triangles around a common quadrilateral is homothetic to the original quadrilateral with homothety center at the intersection of its diagonals. This homothety maps each vertex of the quadrilateral to its adjacent circumcenter along the diagonal.</description>
  <example>For quadrilateral WXYZ, the intersection of diagonals WY and XZ is H. Then O₁ = H + (O₂ – H)·k, where O₁, O₂ are circumcenters of triangles around WY and XZ. The factor k relates the distances from H to the original vertices and to the new circumcenters.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>The area of a homothetic image is the square of the homothety ratio times the original area: Area_new = k²·Area_old. Use this when a new shape is obtained by scaling the original shape from a fixed point.</description>
  <example>If a quadrilateral has area A and its circumcenter polygon is obtained by homothety with ratio k from the same quadrilateral, then the circumcenter polygon’s area is k²·A. For instance, if k = 3/2, the new area is (3/2)²·A = 9/4·A.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When multiple formulas involve the same repeated expression (e.g. the triangle area or side lengths), introduce a variable for it to simplify algebra. This reduces clutter and makes error-checking easier.</description>
  <example>In ΔUVW, let Δ = area(UVW). Then circumradius R = (UV·VW·WU)/(4Δ). If Δ appears in several subsequent steps, replace Δ with a single symbol throughout to streamline the computation.</example>

<note1>
  <description>In any triangle, the circumcenter is the intersection of the perpendicular bisectors of its sides. It lies on the perpendicular bisector of each side and is equidistant from the triangle’s vertices.</description>
  <example>Given a triangle with vertices P, Q, R, construct the perpendicular bisector of PQ and the perpendicular bisector of QR. Their intersection O is the circumcenter, satisfying OP=OQ=OR.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>Opposite sides of a quadrilateral formed by connecting two opposite circumcenters of a cyclic quadrilateral are equal in length. This follows because each segment is the sum or difference of two equal circumradii.</description>
  <example>In a cyclic quadrilateral with circumcenters O₁ and O₂ of triangles sharing one side, the segment O₁O₂ equals the sum of two circumradii minus a common projection, making it equal to the opposite side formed by O₃O₄ for the other pair.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>The circumradii of triangles sharing an edge are equal since they all subtend the same chord. Thus, any quadrilateral formed by their circumcenters has equal adjacent sides.</description>
  <example>For triangles sharing side XY, the circumradius R₁ of ΔX YZ and R₂ of ΔX YW are equal. Hence, the segments connecting circumcenters of ΔX YZ and ΔX YW to the next triangle’s circumcenter are equal in length.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>In any cyclic quadrilateral, the perpendicular bisectors of its sides concur at the circumcenter. Connecting these bisectors’ intersections yields a parallelogram, since each pair of opposite sides are equal and parallel.</description>
  <example>Given cyclic quadrilateral WXYZ, its perpendicular bisectors of WX and YZ meet at O. Connecting O to the bisectors of WY and XZ forms a parallelogram whose opposite sides are equal to the distances between circumcenters of adjacent triangles.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>A quadrilateral with two pairs of equal adjacent sides is a parallelogram. Its area can be computed as the product of one pair of adjacent sides and the sine of the included angle.</description>
  <example>For a parallelogram with side lengths a and b and included angle θ, the area is a·b·sin θ. If a=b, it becomes a²·sin θ, simplifying the computation of area using known trigonometric values.</example>

<note1>
  <description>In any triangle, the circumcenter is the intersection of the perpendicular bisectors of its sides. It lies at the center of the unique circle passing through all three vertices and is equidistant from them.</description>
  <example>For triangle with vertices P, Q, R, draw lines through the midpoints of PQ and PR perpendicular to PQ and PR, respectively; their intersection O is the circumcenter satisfying OP = OQ = OR.</example>
</note2>
  <description>The circumcenter of a triangle with side lengths a, b, c and opposite angles A, B, C can be found by projecting one vertex onto the perpendicular bisector of another side. If a triangle has sides a, b, c, then the distance from one vertex to the circumcenter equals (a·b·c)/(4·Area).</description>
  <example>Given triangle with side lengths 5, 6, 7, compute its area via Heron’s formula or ½·b·c·sin(A), then use (5·6·7)/(4·Area) to find the circumradius R. The circumcenter is then at distance R from each vertex along the perpendicular bisector of the opposite side.</example>
</note3>
  <description>The locus of points equidistant from two fixed points P and Q is the perpendicular bisector of segment PQ. In a quadrilateral formed by circumcenters of four triangles sharing common sides, each pair of adjacent circumcenters lies on a perpendicular bisector of a shared side.</description>
  <example>Let O₁ and O₂ be circumcenters of triangles sharing side AB. Then O₁ and O₂ lie on the perpendicular bisector of AB. Similarly, their neighbors lie on the perpendicular bisectors of the other shared sides, forming a cyclic structure.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Four points are concyclic if and only if the sum of two pairs of opposite angles equals 180°. In a quadrilateral formed by circumcenters, checking that the sum of opposite angles at vertices is 180° confirms it lies on a common circle.</description>
  <example>Given quadrilateral O₁O₂O₃O₄, compute ∠O₁O₂O₃ and ∠O₂O₃O₄. If ∠O₁O₂O₃ + ∠O₂O₃O₄ = 180°, then O₁, O₂, O₃, O₄ are concyclic, and one can apply circle theorems to relate them.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Once a quadrilateral is known to be cyclic, its area can be found by the extended Law of Sines: Area = (a·b·sin(C))/2, where a, b are two adjacent sides and C is the included angle. Alternatively, Brahmagupta’s formula gives Area = √[(s–a)(s–b)(s–c)(s–d)] for a cyclic quadrilateral with semiperimeter s = (a+b+c+d)/2.</description>
  <example>For a cyclic quadrilateral with side lengths a, b, c, d and opposite angles A, C, one can compute its area as ½·a·b·sin(C) + ½·c·d·sin(A) or use Brahmagupta’s formula √[(s–a)(s–b)(s–c)(s–d)] with s = (a+b+c+d)/2.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Area of a triangle via two sides and the included angle is ½·(side₁)·(side₂)·sin(included angle). Use this when two sides and their included angle are known, avoiding Heron’s formula.</description>
  <example>In △XYZ, sides XY=5, XZ=7, and ∠Y XZ=60°. Then [X Y Z]=½·5·7·sin60°=½·35·(√3/2)=87.5·√3/4≈11.9. This avoids computing the third side or the circumradius.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a point P divides side BC in ratio m:n, the area of △P B C to △A B C is m/(m+n). This follows from the fact that triangles on the same altitude have areas proportional to their bases.</description>
  <example>In △ABC, let P on BC satisfy BP:PC=2:3. Then [P B C]/[A B C]=2/(2+3)=2/5. Thus the smaller triangle occupies 40% of the whole.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>The Angle Bisector Theorem states that an internal angle bisector divides the opposite side in the ratio of the adjacent sides. Use it when a ray from a vertex bisects the angle at that vertex.</description>
  <example>In △XYZ, ray YW bisects ∠XYZ. If XY=4 and YZ=6, then WX:XZ=4:6=2:3. So WX is 2/5 of WZ and XZ is 3/5 of WZ.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>The Law of Sines: In any triangle, a/sin(A)=b/sin(B)=c/sin(C). Use it to find unknown angles or sides when two angles and one side (or two sides and a non-included angle) are known.</description>
  <example>In △ABC, ∠A=30°, ∠B=45°, and side a=10. Then b=10·sin45°/sin30°=10·(√2/2)/(1/2)=10√2. This yields side b without computing the third side or altitude.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Mass Points: Assign weights to vertices so that each cevian balances. The ratio in which a cevian divides a side equals the ratio of the opposite vertex’s mass to the sum of the other two masses.</description>
  <example>In △ABC, point D on BC satisfies BD:DC=2:3. Assign mass 3 at B and mass 2 at C. Then the mass at A is 5. To find where the cevian from A meets BC, use those masses directly.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Angle Bisector Theorem: In any triangle, an internal angle bisector divides the opposite side into segments proportional to the adjacent sides, i.e. if a bisector from vertex V meets side W→X at point P, then WP:PX = VW:VX.</description>
  <example>In triangle VWX with VW=4 and VX=6, an internal bisector from V meets WX at P. Then WP:PX = 4:6 = 2:3.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Area Ratio by Side-Segment Ratio: If a point P divides side XY of triangle ABC, then the area ratio [APC]/[ABC] equals the ratio XP:XY. More generally, [APC]/[ABC] = XP/XY.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, let P lie on BC with BP:PC = 1:2. Then [APC]/[ABC] = PC/BC = 2/3.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>Mass Point Geometry: Assign “masses” to vertices so that side-segment ratios become lever balances. A point P on XY satisfies XP:X Y = mass at Y:mass at X. This method computes multiple segment ratios simultaneously.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, let D on AB satisfy AD:DB = 2:3, and E on AC satisfy AE:EC = 4:1. Assign masses 3 at A, 2 at B, and 1 at C. Then D and E balance, and you can find BE:ED.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
