  <description>Trigonometric Area Formula: The area of triangle ABC can be written as ½·AB·AC·sin(∠BAC). This is useful when a given angle is involved and side lengths are known.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC with AB=5, AC=7, and ∠BAC=60°, the area is ½·5·7·sin60° = 17.5·(√3/2) = (35√3)/4.</example>
</note5>
  <note6>
  <description>Area Ratios via Altitudes: If two triangles share the same altitude from a vertex, their area ratio equals the ratio of their bases. Conversely, if they share the same base, the ratio equals the ratio of their altitudes.</description>
  <example>Triangles ABD and ACD share altitude from A on line BD. If BD is divided at P so that BP:PD = 3:2, then [ABP]/[APD] = BP:PD = 3:2.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Angle Bisector Theorem: In any triangle, an internal angle bisector divides the opposite side into segments proportional to the adjacent sides. Formally, if an angle at vertex A is bisected, then the two segments on BC satisfy BD/DC = AB/AC.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, the bisector of ∠A meets BC at D. If AB = 5 and AC = 7, then BD/DC = 5/7, so if BC = 12, BD = 5 and DC = 7.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Stewart’s Theorem: For a triangle with sides of lengths a, b, c and a cevian of length d dividing side a into segments m and n, the relation holds: b²·m + c²·n = a(d² + m·n). It is used to find unknown lengths of cevians or to relate areas via side segments.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC with BC = a, AB = c, AC = b, and a cevian AD dividing BC into BD = m and DC = n, Stewart’s theorem gives c²·m + b²·n = a(d² + m·n), allowing d or one of m,n to be solved.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Area Ratio via Side Segment Ratio: In any triangle, if a point divides one side in the ratio m:n, then the areas of the two sub-triangles sharing the same altitude from the opposite vertex are in the ratio m:n. This follows from (1/2·base·height) proportionality.</description>
  <example>Let D be on BC of triangle ABC with BD/DC = 3/2. Then area(ABD)/area(ADC) = 3/2, since both triangles share altitude from A.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Mass Point Geometry: Assign weights to vertices so that each cevian balances like a lever. The ratio in which a cevian divides a side equals the ratio of the opposite vertex’s weight to the sum of the other two weights. This technique streamlines ratio and area computations.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, suppose AD divides BC in ratio BD/DC = 2/3. Assign weight 3 at B and weight 2 at C; then the mass at A can be chosen so that AD balances, and area ratios follow directly from these weights.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Angle Bisector Theorem: In any triangle, an internal angle bisector divides the opposite side into segments proportional to the adjacent sides. Formally, if a point D on BC satisfies ∠BAD = ∠DAC, then BD/DC = AB/AC.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC with AB = 5 and AC = 7, the bisector of ∠A meets BC at D. Then BD/DC = 5/7, so if BC = 12, BD = (5/12)·12 = 5 and DC = 7.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Internal Similarity: If two points on the sides of a triangle satisfy equal angles at the third vertex, the smaller triangle formed by these points is similar to the original. Corresponding sides are in the same ratio.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, let E on AB and F on AC satisfy ∠BEC = ∠BFC. Then ∠EBC = ∠FCB and ∠BEC = ∠BFC, so ∆BEC ∼ ∆BFC with BE/BC = BF/BC = BE/BF.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Area Ratio via Side-Splitting: For any triangle, the ratio of areas of two subtriangles sharing the same altitude equals the ratio of their bases. Hence, if a point P on BC divides it into BP and PC, then [APB]/[APC] = BP/PC.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, let P be on BC with BP/PC = 3/5. If A is above BC, then [APB]/[APC] = 3/5, since both share altitude from A to BC.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Mass Point Geometry: Assign masses at vertices so that the weighted sum of masses at endpoints of a side equals the mass at the dividing point. The ratio in which the point splits a side equals the inverse ratio of the masses at the endpoints.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC, if D on BC satisfies BD/DC = 2/3, assign mass 3 at B and 2 at C. Then D balances these masses, and any cevian from A to D can be handled by summing the masses at A, B, and C.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Stewart’s Theorem: In triangle ABC with a cevian AD meeting BC at D, the relation AB²·DC + AC²·BD = AD²·BC + BD·DC·BC holds. It allows computation of a cevian length or segment ratios without coordinates.</description>
  <example>In triangle ABC with AB = 4, AC = 5, BC = 6, and D on BC with BD = 2, DC = 4, Stewart’s gives 4²·4 + 5²·2 = AD²·6 + 2·4·6, so AD² = (16·4 + 25·2 – 48)/6 = (64 + 50 – 48)/6 = 66/6 = 11, hence AD = √11.</example>

<note1>
  <description>For any quadrilateral inscribed in a circle, the sum of each pair of opposite angles equals 180°. This lets you relate unknown interior angles when five or more points lie on a circle.</description>
  <example>Suppose points P, Q, R, S lie on a circle. If ∠PQR = 70°, then ∠PSR = 110° because they are opposite angles.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>The Law of Cosines relates the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles: for triangle XYZ, x² = y² + z² − 2yz·cos(∠Y). Use this to find an angle or side when three sides or two sides and the included angle are known.</description>
  <example>In triangle XYZ, if XY = a, YZ = b, XZ = c, then cos(∠Y) = (a² + b² − c²)/(2ab). If a = 5, b = 7, c = 8, then ∠Y = arccos((25 + 49 − 64)/(70)) = arccos(10/70).</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>In a circle of radius R, the chord length opposite an inscribed angle θ is given by 2R·sin(θ). This converts a geometric chord problem into a trigonometric one.</description>
  <example>For a circle of radius 10 and an inscribed angle of 30°, the chord length is 2·10·sin(30°) = 20·0.5 = 10.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When a point M is the midpoint of segment AE, the Law of Cosines applied to triangle AME yields AM² = AE²/4 + EM² + AE·EM·cos(θ), where θ is the angle between AE and EM. This helps relate distances involving the midpoint.</description>
  <example>Let AE = d and EM = e, with angle ∠AEM = φ. Then AM = ½·√(d² + e² − 2de·cos(φ)).</example>
</note6>
<note7>
  <description>The Power of a Point theorem states that for any point P and circle, the product of the lengths of segments from P to the two intersection points with the circle is constant. Use it to relate distances from P to two chords.</description>
  <example>If a line through P meets the circle at U and V, and another line through P meets at W and X, then PU·PV = PW·PX. For instance, if PU = 3 and PV = 4, then any other chord through P has products matching 12.</example>

<note1>
  <description>
In an isosceles trapezoid, the nonparallel sides are equal in length and the base angles at each base are equal. This symmetry allows one to drop perpendiculars from the endpoints of one base to the other to create right triangles. 
</description>
  <example>
Consider a trapezoid with bases of lengths b₁ and b₂ and nonparallel sides of length s. Dropping perpendiculars from the endpoints of the shorter base to the longer base splits the longer base into three segments: two equal segments of length (b₂−b₁)/2 and one central segment of length b₁. The right triangles then have legs (b₂−b₁)/2 and the height h, with hypotenuse s.
</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>
The Pythagorean theorem relates the legs and hypotenuse of a right triangle: if the legs have lengths a and b and the hypotenuse has length c, then a² + b² = c². Use this to find any one of the three lengths when the other two are known. 
</description>
  <example>
In a right triangle with legs of lengths 3 and 4, the hypotenuse is c = √(3² + 4²) = 5. Conversely, if the hypotenuse is 10 and one leg is 6, the other leg is √(10² − 6²) = 8.
</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>
A point lies on a circle of radius R centered at O if and only if the distance from O to that point equals R. For any two points P and Q on the same circle, the length PQ can be found by the chord length formula: PQ = 2R·sin(∠POQ/2), where ∠POQ is the central angle subtended by PQ. 
</description>
  <example>
In a circle of radius 5, two points P and Q subtend a central angle of 60°. Then the chord PQ = 2·5·sin(60°/2) = 10·sin(30°) = 5. 
</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>
The midpoint M of a segment AB has coordinates that are the averages of the corresponding coordinates of A and B. If A = (x₁,y₁) and B = (x₂,y₂), then M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2). This is useful for simplifying coordinate geometry problems. 
</description>
  <example>
Given points A = (1,2) and B = (5,6), the midpoint M is ((1+5)/2, (2+6)/2) = (3,4). 
</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>
The Law of Cosines generalizes the Pythagorean theorem to any triangle: for sides a, b, c with opposite angles A, B, C, one has c² = a² + b² − 2ab·cos(C). Use it to find an unknown side or angle when two sides and their included angle or all three sides are known. 
</description>
  <example>
In a triangle with sides of lengths 7 and 9 and included angle 60°, the third side is c = √(7² + 9² − 2·7·9·cos(60°)) = √(49 + 81 − 126·0.5) = √(130 − 63) = √67.
</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Midpoint Lemma: In any triangle, the segment joining the midpoints of two sides is parallel to the third side and half its length. Use this to relate lengths and parallelism in trapezoid and cyclic configurations.</description>
  <example>In triangle PQR, let M and N be midpoints of PQ and PR. Then MN ∥ QR and MN = ½·QR. This can be used to show that certain quadrilaterals are parallelograms or to derive parallel lines in cyclic figures.</example>
</note2>
  <description>Parallelism and Angle Chasing: In an isosceles trapezoid, the legs are equal and the base angles are equal. Use parallel lines (bases) to transfer angles and establish cyclic quadrilaterals or equal angles for further deductions.</description>
  <example>Given trapezoid WXYZ with WX ∥ YZ and WX = YZ, one has ∠WXY = ∠YZX. If a point K lies on YZ extended, then ∠WXY = ∠KYZ, showing that W, Y, Z, K are concyclic or that certain angles are supplementary.</example>
</note3>
  <description>Ptolemy’s Theorem: For any cyclic quadrilateral with sides a, b, c, d and diagonals p, q, one has a·c + b·d = p·q. Use this to relate side lengths and diagonals when five points lie on a circle.</description>
  <example>In cyclic quadrilateral ABCD, if AB = 6, BC = 8, CD = 10, DA = 12, and diagonal AC = 13, then by Ptolemy, 6·10 + 8·12 = 13·BD, so BD = (60 + 96)/13 = 12.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Power of a Point: For a point E outside a circle, if a secant through E meets the circle at A and B (with A closer to E), then EA·EB equals the square of the tangent length from E. This relates distances from E to intersecting chords.</description>
  <example>Let E be outside a circle with tangent ET = 3. A secant from E meets the circle at A and B, with EA = 2. Then EB = (ET)²/EA = 9/2. This can be used to find unknown segment lengths on secants.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Law of Cosines in Cyclic Contexts: In any triangle, a² = b² + c² − 2bc·cos(A). When points lie on a circle, use this to find angles or side lengths, especially when two sides and the included angle are known.</description>
  <example>In triangle DEF inscribed in a circle of radius R, if DE = p, EF = q, and ∠DEF = θ, then DF² = p² + q² − 2pq·cos(θ). For θ = 60°, DF² = p² + q² − pq, which can be used to compute DF given p and q.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Four points lie on a circle if and only if the perpendicular bisectors of any two chords between them intersect. Equivalently, the power of a point formula or the cyclic quadrilateral angle property can be used to check collinearity.</description>
  <example>Given points P, Q, R, S, construct the perpendicular bisectors of PR and QS; if they meet at a single point O, then P, Q, R, S are concyclic. Alternatively, verify ∠PQR + ∠PSR = 180°.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>In an isosceles trapezoid, the nonparallel sides (legs) are congruent, and the base angles adjacent to each base are equal. These properties yield symmetry and equal-length relations useful in coordinate or synthetic proofs.</description>
  <example>Label the trapezoid with bases BC and AD and legs AB, CD. Then AB = CD and ∠ABC = ∠BCD, ∠BAD = ∠ADC. Use these equalities to place coordinates symmetrically or to relate angles in angle-chasing.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>The Power of a Point theorem states that for any point P and a circle, if a line through P meets the circle at X and Y, then PX·PY is constant. This can relate segments from P to points on the circle or to tangents.</description>
  <example>Let P be a point outside a circle, and let the secant through P meet the circle at U and V. Then PU·PV equals the square of the tangent length from P. Use this to find unknown segment lengths when one segment is known.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>The Midpoint-Radius Relation in a circle: for any chord AB and its midpoint M, the perpendicular from the circle’s center O to the chord passes through M, and OM² + (AB/2)² = R², where R is the radius.</description>
  <example>Given a circle of radius R, a chord AB, and its midpoint M, drop the perpendicular from O to meet AB at M. Then OM² + (AB/2)² = R². Use this to compute OM when AB is known or vice versa.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>In a circle of radius R, any central angle θ (in radians) subtends an arc length s = Rθ and a chord length c = 2R·sin(θ/2). These formulas link angles, arc lengths, and chord lengths.</description>
  <example>A chord subtends a central angle of 60° in a circle of radius R. Then its chord length is c = 2R·sin(30°) = R. Use these to convert between angles at the center and chord lengths.</example>

<note1>
  <description>The circumradius of a right triangle equals half the hypotenuse. In a right triangle with legs a and b and hypotenuse c, the circumcenter lies at the midpoint of the hypotenuse, so R = c/2. This lets you convert given circumradii directly into the lengths of corresponding hypotenuses.</description>
  <example>Given a right triangle with legs 6 and 8, the hypotenuse is 10, so its circumradius is 10/2 = 5. Conversely, if a right triangle has circumradius 7, its hypotenuse must be 14.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>In any triangle, the circumradius formula R = a/(2 sin A) relates a side a to its opposite angle A. This is useful when you know a circumradius and an angle but need the corresponding side length.</description>
  <example>For a triangle with circumradius 10 and an angle of 30° opposite side a, we get a = 2 R sin 30° = 2×10×½ = 10.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>For an acute triangle, the circumradius satisfies R > a/2 for each side a, since sin A > a/(2 R) when A is acute. This inequality can detect invalid constructions or help bound unknown sides.</description>
  <example>If a triangle’s circumradius is 8 but one side is claimed to be 17, then R > a/2 gives 8 > 17/2 = 8.5, which is false, so that side cannot be 17 in an acute triangle.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>The Law of Cosines, c² = a² + b² − 2ab cos C, connects side lengths and the cosine of the included angle. Use it to express one side in terms of others and the angle, especially when angles are known or can be related.</description>
  <example>In a triangle with sides a = 5, b = 7, and included angle C = 60°, the third side c satisfies c² = 25 + 49 − 2×5×7×½ = 74 − 35 = 39, so c = √39.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When a point satisfies multiple geometric constraints (e.g. perpendicularity and equal circumradii), combine these using distance formulas and angle relations to form a system of equations. Solving that system yields the desired lengths.</description>
  <example>Suppose point P is at distances 5 and 13 from two fixed points A and B, and ∠APB = 90°. Using AP² + BP² = AB² gives 25 + 169 = AB², so AB = √194. If this also matches a given acute circumradius condition, consistency confirms the solution.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>  
The circumradius of any triangle with sides a, b, c and area Δ is given by R = (a·b·c)/(4Δ). This formula follows from the extended Law of Sines and applies to all triangles.  
</description>
  <example>  
For a triangle with side lengths 5, 6, and 7, first compute its area via Heron’s formula: s=(5+6+7)/2=9, Δ=√[9·4·3·2]=√216=6√6. Then R=(5·6·7)/(4·6√6)=210/(24√6)=35/(4√6).  
</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>  
In a right triangle with legs of lengths x and y and hypotenuse c, the circumradius is R = c/2. This follows because the hypotenuse is the diameter of the circumcircle.  
</description>
  <example>  
A right triangle has legs of lengths 8 and 15, so its hypotenuse is c=√(8²+15²)=17. Thus its circumradius is R=17/2=8.5.  
</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>  
If two triangles share the same circumcircle, then their orthocenters are symmetric with respect to the circle’s center. This symmetry can relate the altitudes and distances from the center to the sides.  
</description>
  <example>  
Consider two triangles inscribed in the same circle. If one triangle’s altitude from one vertex is 6 units, then the other triangle’s corresponding altitude is also 6 units, because their orthocenters are reflections across the circumcenter.  
</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>  
In any cyclic quadrilateral, Ptolemy’s theorem states that the product of the diagonals equals the sum of the products of opposite sides: d₁·d₂ = a·c + b·d. This is useful for relating side lengths when a cyclic quadrilateral is formed.  
</description>
  <example>  
A cyclic quadrilateral has sides of lengths 3, 4, 5, and 6 in order. If its diagonals are d₁ and d₂, then d₁·d₂ = 3·5 + 4·6 = 15 + 24 = 39.  
</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>  
When a point X inside a rectangle subtends a right angle at A and B, X lies on the circle with diameter AB. This circle’s center is the midpoint of AB, and its radius is half of AB.  
</description>
  <example>  
In a rectangle with side lengths a and b, if X satisfies ∠AXB=90°, then X is on the circle centered at the midpoint of AB with radius a/2. Thus any point X on that circle will form a right angle at A and B.  
</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>In any triangle with circumradius R and side length a, the formula a = 2R sin A relates its side to its opposite angle and the circumradius. Use this to express unknown side lengths in terms of known angles and R.</description>
  <example>For a triangle with circumradius R and an angle of 30° opposite side a, compute a = 2·R·sin 30° = R.</example>
</note2>
  <description>The Law of Sines states that for any triangle, a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C = 2R. This lets you convert between side ratios and angle measures or between angles and circumradii.</description>
  <example>In a triangle where one side is b and the angle opposite is B, and the circumradius is R, then b = 2R sin B. If B = 45° and R = 10, then b = 2·10·sin 45° = 10√2.</example>
</note3>
  <description>The circumradius of a right triangle can be found by R = (hypotenuse)/2. When two triangles share an angle and one is right-angled, their circumradii can be compared to that shared angle.</description>
  <example>For a right triangle with hypotenuse h, its circumradius is R = h/2. If h = 14, then R = 7.</example>
</note4>
  <description>When triangles share an interior or exterior angle, the Law of Sines yields ratios of their sides that equal the ratio of their circumradii. This allows solving for unknown sides or angles.</description>
  <example>Triangles 1 and 2 share angle θ. If triangle 1 has circumradius R₁ and triangle 2 has R₂, then side₁/sin θ = side₂/sin θ = 2R₁ for triangle 1 and similarly for 2. Hence side₁/side₂ = R₁/R₂.</example>
</note5>
  <description>After establishing side-angle relationships, solve the resulting algebraic equations (often quadratic) for the unknown lengths or angles. Always check that solutions are positive and satisfy the triangle’s angle-sum condition.</description>
  <example>From side₁/s = k and side₂ = m, solve s = side₁/k and verify 0 < s < m and the total of all sides is positive before accepting the solution.</example>

<note1>
  <description>
In any triangle, the circumradius R is given by R = (a b c) / (4 · area). This links side lengths and area to the circle’s radius.
</description>
  <example>
Consider a triangle with sides 3, 4, and 5. Its area is ½·3·4 = 6, so the circumradius is R = (3·4·5)/(4·6) = 60/24 = 2.5.
</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>
When two triangles share a common side or angle, their circumradii relate via that shared element. In particular, if two triangles share a side s, then R₁/R₂ = (a₁·b₁·c₁)/(a₂·b₂·c₂) simplifies by s² in both numerators and denominators, yielding R₁/R₂ = (other sides of first)/(other sides of second).
</description>
  <example>
Two triangles with shared side s = 4 have circumradii R₁ = 5 and R₂ = 3. If the triangles differ in side lengths a and b, then 5/3 = a·b/ (4·c), which can be solved for the unknown sides.
</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>
In a rectangle, the diagonals are congruent and bisect each other. Thus, if X is a point inside, the distances from X to the four corners satisfy XA² + XC² = XB² + XD², and XC = XD.
</description>
  <example>
In a rectangle with sides 6 and 8, the diagonal length is √(6²+8²)=10. If X is inside and XA = 3, then XC = 10²−3² = 91, so X to the opposite corner is √91.
</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>
A right angle at X implies X lies on the circle with AB as diameter (Thales’ theorem). For any point Y on that circle, ∠AYB = 90°. Thus, if ∠AXB = 90°, then X is on the circle whose diameter is AB.
</description>
  <example>
If AB is a segment of length 10, then any point X that makes ∠AXB = 90° must lie on the circle with AB as diameter, whose radius is 5.
</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>
To find the unknown side of a rectangle when you know distances from an interior point to three corners, set up the diagonal relations XA² + XC² = XB² + XD² and use the fact that XA + XC = XB + XD. Solve the resulting system for the missing side.
</description>
  <example>
Suppose in a rectangle with sides x and y, XA = 5, XC = 7, XB = 6, XD = 8. Then 5²+7² = 6²+8² gives 25+49 = 36+64, which holds. Using XA + XC = XB + XD (5+7=6+8) also checks out, confirming consistency.
</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a plane intersects a right rectangular prism, the intersection is an n-gon whose side lengths are chords of the prism’s edges. The longest side corresponds to the prism’s longest edge, and other sides are projections of the midpoints of edges onto the plane.</description>
  <example>Suppose a prism has edges of lengths a, b, c. A plane cutting through its midpoints yields an intersection whose sides are chords of lengths a, b, c, arranged in the order they appear along the edges. The longest chord is the prism’s longest edge, and the others follow from orthogonal projections.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Project each edge of the prism onto the plane by dropping perpendiculars from the endpoints. Each side of the intersection polygon is the projection of an edge segment, given by the formula projected_length = |original_length|·cos θ, where θ is the dihedral angle between the prism face and the cutting plane.</description>
  <example>If an edge of length L is at angle θ to the cutting plane, then its projection onto the plane is L·cos θ. For instance, if the prism’s face angle is 60° and the cutting plane is at a 30° tilt, the projection is L·cos 30°.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Identify the longest chord in the intersection as the prism’s longest edge. Use this to set up the equation for the dihedral angle θ between the prism’s face and the cutting plane: longest_edge_length = face_edge_length·cos θ.</description>
  <example>Given that the prism has edges a, b, c (with c the longest) and the intersection chord is c, one writes c = a·cos θ. Solving gives cos θ = c/a, which yields θ = arccos(c/a).</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Relate the distance d from the prism’s center to the cutting plane via the right triangle formed by d and the prism’s half-edge. Specifically, d = half_edge_length·sin θ, where θ is the dihedral angle from note 3.</description>
  <example>If the prism’s half-edge is H and the plane makes angle θ with the prism face, then d = H·sin θ. For instance, if H = 5 and θ = 30°, then d = 5·sin 30° = 2.5.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Validate the computed distance by checking that all projected edge lengths satisfy the original intersection side lengths. Ensure consistency with the prism’s geometry and the sum of squares of projected lengths matches the sum of squares of the actual edges.</description>
  <example>After finding d and θ, compute each projected length L_i = L_i·cos θ and verify they match the given intersection sides. Also confirm that d = H·sin θ and that projected lengths sum correctly to the total edge lengths.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When a plane cuts a rectangular prism, the intersection is a polygon whose side lengths relate to the prism’s edge lengths via orthogonal projections. Each side of the polygon is the projection of a prism edge onto the plane, so its length equals the prism edge length times the cosine of the angle between that edge and the plane.</description>
  <example>Suppose a prism has edges of lengths a, b, c, and a plane makes angle θ with the prism’s c-axis. The side of the intersection corresponding to edge b has length b·cosθ.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>To find the angle between a line and a plane, use the relation sinθ = |line→·normal|/|line→||normal|, where line→ is a direction vector of the line and normal is the plane’s normal. This gives the sine of the dihedral angle between the line and the plane.</description>
  <example>Given a line direction vector v and plane normal n, compute sinθ = |v·n|/(|v||n|). For instance, if v·n = 3, |v| = 5, |n| = 4, then sinθ = 3/20.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>If the prism is centered at the origin, the distance d from the center to the plane can be expressed as d = (a·cosθ₁ + b·cosθ₂ + c·cosθ₃)/√(sin²θ₁ + sin²θ₂ + sin²θ₃), where θᵢ are the angles between each axis and the plane. This follows from summing the projections of the prism’s edges onto the plane’s normal.</description>
  <example>For a centered prism with edge projections p₁, p₂, p₃ onto the plane’s normal, and sinθ₁ = 0.2, sinθ₂ = 0.3, sinθ₃ = 0.4, then d = (p₁+ p₂+ p₃)/√(0.2²+0.3²+0.4²).</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>The sum of the squares of the sine of the dihedral angles between the three coordinate planes and the cutting plane equals one: sin²θ₁ + sin²θ₂ + sin²θ₃ = 1. This orthogonality condition ensures the plane is well-defined in space.</description>
  <example>If sinθ₁ = 0.6, sinθ₂ = 0.8, then sinθ₃ must satisfy sin²θ₃ = 1 − (0.6²+0.8²) = 0, so θ₃ = 0 (i.e., the plane coincides with the third coordinate plane).</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>When a plane cuts a rectangular prism, the intersection is a polygon whose side lengths equal the distances between the prism’s edges parallel to those sides, multiplied by the plane’s normal’s components. This follows from projecting edges onto the plane’s normal.</description>
  <example>Suppose a prism has edge lengths a, b, c, and the cutting plane has normal vector (n₁,n₂,n₃). Then the intersection has sides of lengths |n₁·a|, |n₂·b|, |n₃·c|, etc., in the order corresponding to which face each side projects from.</example>
</note2>
  <description>For a rectangular prism of side lengths a, b, c, any plane intersects its edges at points whose distances from a chosen vertex satisfy linear relations. Specifically, if the plane’s normal components are (n₁,n₂,n₃), then the distances along the edges are proportional to (|n₁|,|n₂|,|n₃|).</description>
  <example>Consider a prism with edges of lengths a, b, c. A plane with normal (n₁,n₂,n₃) intersects the edges from the origin at points (d₁,0,0), (0,d₂,0), (0,0,d₃) where d₁ = |n₁|·a, d₂ = |n₂|·b, d₃ = |n₃|·c.</example>
</note3>
  <description>To find the plane’s normal components from its intersection side lengths, set up equations dᵢ = |nᵢ|·Lᵢ for each side length dᵢ and corresponding prism edge Lᵢ. Solve the resulting system for |nᵢ|, then determine the sign of each nᵢ by the order of the intersection polygon.</description>
  <example>Given intersection sides d₁,d₂,d₃ and prism edges a,b,c, solve |n₁|·a = d₁, |n₂|·b = d₂, |n₃|·c = d₃ for |nᵢ|. Then assign n₁,n₂,n₃ their correct signs so that the polygon’s vertices appear in the expected cyclic order.</example>
</note4>
  <description>The distance D from the prism’s center to the plane can be computed as the dot product of the center’s edge-coordinates with the normalized normal vector: D = (|n₁|·a/2 + |n₂|·b/2 + |n₃|·c/2) / √(n₁² + n₂² + n₃²).</description>
  <example>With prism center at (a/2,b/2,c/2) and normal (n₁,n₂,n₃), compute D = [(a|n₁|+b|n₂|+c|n₃|)/2] / √(n₁²+n₂²+n₃²), giving the perpendicular distance from the center to the cutting plane.</example>
</note5>
  <description>A quick consistency check is to verify that the sum of the squares of the intersection side lengths equals the sum of the squares of the prism’s edge lengths times the square of the plane’s unit normal’s components: ∑dᵢ² = (a²+b²+c²)(n₁²+n₂²+n₃²).</description>
  <example>If prism edges a,b,c give a²+b²+c² = S and intersection sides d₁,d₂,d₃ give ∑dᵢ² = T, then ensure T = S·(n₁²+n₂²+n₃²). If this holds, the computed normal components and distance are consistent.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When a plane cuts a right prism, the intersection is a polygon whose side lengths equal the distances between the parallel faces of the prism along the direction of the cut. This holds because the plane slices through each lateral face at a constant offset.</description>
  <example>Consider a right prism with a rectangular base and side lengths a and b, and height h. A plane parallel to the base at distance d from one base cuts the prism. The resulting hexagon has three side lengths a, three side lengths b, and the remaining sides equal to the distances between the two bases along the direction of the cut, which are both h.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Label the prism’s face-edge distances as a, b, c (for the three distinct face pairs). If the cutting plane intersects the prism at distances x and y from two opposite faces, then the side lengths of the intersection polygon alternate as a, b, c, a, b, c, and the sum of opposite sides equals a+b+c.</description>
  <example>For a prism with face-edge distances a=3, b=4, c=5, a plane at distance x=1 from one base and y=2 from the opposite base gives an intersection with side lengths 3,4,5,3,4,5, since each face-edge distance appears twice.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>Use the property that in any alternating sequence of side lengths a, b, c, a, b, c, the sum of the first and fourth sides equals the sum of the second and fifth sides, and similarly for the third and sixth. This yields equations like a+c = b+d and b+c = a+e.</description>
  <example>Given sides [45,66,63,55,54,77], note that 45+55 = 100 and 66+54 = 120, so the third side 63 plus the sixth side 77 must also sum to 120 (63+77=140), which is inconsistent. This inconsistency signals a mislabeling or error in the problem statement.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>Translate the alternating-sum constraints into a system of linear equations in x and y (the distances from the two opposite faces). Solve for x and y to find the plane’s offset from one base.</description>
  <example>For face-edge distances a=2, b=3, c=4, and observed sides [2,3,4,2,3,4], set up x+y = 2+3 = 5 and 3x+4y = 2+4 = 6. Solving gives x=2, y=3, so the plane is at distance 2 from one base and 3 from the other.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>Compute the distance from the prism’s center to the cutting plane by averaging the distances to the two opposite faces: distance = (x + y)/2. This is valid because the center lies midway between those faces.</description>
  <example>If x=1 and y=3, then the center-to-plane distance is (1+3)/2 = 2. This yields the final answer without computing any angles or normals.</example>
</note1>
